questions.title: JJS 06 01 01 Sketch a diagram
JJS 06 01 02 Which one
questions.prompt: # Which one of these diagrams best matches your sketch and our mental model after that code runs?

answer.description:
**B is the correct diagram.** All variables point to the same "mustache" string value.

None of the other diagrams match our mental model because they show more than one "mustache" string value. In our universe, every distinct string only exists once.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612898922/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-01-b.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612898922/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-01-b.jpg)

questions.title: JJS 06 02 Use Sketch to Determine Output
questions.prompt:
Now **use this sketch** to determine the output of:

1. **console.log(fingernails === toes);**
2. **console.log(toes === nose);**
3. **console.log(nose === fingernails);**

Hint: usually, a === b when a and b point to the same value.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612898922/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-01-b.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612898922/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-01-b.jpg)

answer.description:
All of these examples print true.

1. fingernails === toes: This is true because fingernails and toes point at the same string.
2. toes === nose: This is true because toes and nose point at the same string.
3. nose === fingernails: This is true because nose and fingernails point at the same string.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612898922/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-01-b.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612898922/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-01-b.jpg)

questions.title: JJS 06 03 01 Sketch a diagram
JJS 06 03 02 Which one
questions.prompt: # Which one of these diagrams best matches your sketch and our mental model after that code runs?

answer.description:
**C is the correct diagram.** It shows each variable pointing at a different object value.

Remember that {} means “create a new object value”, and let x = y means “point x’s wire to the current value of y”. If you follow each line of code in this example step by step, you will arrive at the same result.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612899693/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-03-c.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612899693/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-03-c.jpg)

questions.title: JJS 06 04 Determine Output of Tomato Oregano Potato
questions.prompt:
Now **use this sketch** to determine the output of:

1. **console.log(tomato === oregano);**
2. **console.log(oregano === potato);**
3. **console.log(potato === tomato);**

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612899693/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-03-c.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612899693/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-03-c.jpg)

answer.description:
**All of these examples print `false`.**

1. **tomato === oregano**: This is **false** because tomato and oregano point at different objects.
2. **oregano === potato**: This is **false** because oregano and potato point at different objects.
3. **potato === tomato**: This is **false** because potato and tomato point at different objects.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612899693/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-03-c.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612899693/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-03-c.jpg)

questions.title: JJS 06 05 Tree Stone Water Diagram
questions.prompt:
**Look at this diagram of variables and values.** Write three lines of code that, when executed, would lead to this diagram.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1613065661/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs06-05-question.png](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1613065661/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs06-05-question.png)

questions.title: JJS 06 06 Ticket Message Appear
JJS 06 07 Ticket Message Appear
JJS 06 08 Ticket ID not 0

answer.description:
**The other value that would cause the message to be printed is -0.**

Even though 0 and -0 are two different values, === considers them equal.

questions.title: JJS 06 09 01 Sketch a diagram
JJS 06 09 02 Which one
questions.prompt: # Which one of these diagrams best matches your sketch and our mental model after that code runs?

answer.description:
**D is the correct diagram.** It shows tea and coffee pointing to two different function values, while matcha and latte are pointing to the same NaN value.

Diagram A is wrong because it shows matcha and latte pointing to two different NaN values. In our universe, there is only one NaN value.

Diagrams B and C are wrong because they show tea and coffee pointing to the same value. Each function definition creates a new value, so tea and coffee should point to two different values.

As a reminder, NaN is a special numeric value that represents an invalid result — like when you try to calculate 0 / 0.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612902727/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-09-d.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612902727/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-09-d.jpg)

questions.title: JJS 06 10 Sketch Tea Coffee Matcha Latte
questions.prompt:
Now **use this sketch** to determine the output of:

1. **console.log(tea === coffee);**
2. **console.log(Object.is(tea, coffee));**
3. **console.log(matcha === latte);**
4. **console.log(Object.is(matcha, latte));**

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612902619/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-09-c.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612902619/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-09-c.jpg)

answer.description:
**Only Object.is(matcha, latte) is true, all the other answers are false.**

1. **tea === coffee** — This is **false** because tea and coffee point at two different function values.
2. **Object.is(tea, coffee)** — This is **false** because tea and coffee point at two different function values.
3. **matcha === latte** — This is **false** because both of them point at NaN, and NaN === NaN is always false. (If you forgot about this, you can re-read the section about special cases of Strict Equality.)
4. **Object.is(matcha, latte)** — This is **true** because matcha and latte point at the same NaN number value.

![https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612902727/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-09-d.jpg](https://res.cloudinary.com/dg3gyk0gu/image/upload/v1612902727/just-javascript-email-images/jj06/Quiz%20Images/jjs-06-09-d.jpg)
